    <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      I reported a first finding of this (before I understood the deeper impact here) but it got closed as wont-fix. I tried to contact you in the original report but have gotten no answer, so I will try opening the new report. The other report is <span class="line"><!---->I reported a first finding of this (before I understood the deeper impact here) but it got closed as wont-fix. I tried to contact you in the original report but have gotten no answer, so I will try opening the new report. The other report is <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1354624<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1354624"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1354624<!----></a> . I am sorry if this is the wrong way to go about this. Please reply to me with instructions if you want me to take this some other way.<span class="line"><!----> . I am sorry if this is the wrong way to go about this. Please reply to me with instructions if you want me to take this some other way.<!----></span><br><br># VULNERABILITY DETAILS<span class="line"><!----># VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></span><br>The navigation API allows a CSP/sandboxed document to perform multiple actions that violate these restrictions. I have so far identified three actions that have a security impact. The API allows<span class="line"><!---->The navigation API allows a CSP/sandboxed document to perform multiple actions that violate these restrictions. I have so far identified three actions that have a security impact. The API allows<!----></span><br><br>1. Bypassing CSP script-src by navigating another window to a javascript URL<span class="line"><!---->1. Bypassing CSP script-src by navigating another window to a javascript URL<!----></span><br>2. Bypassing sandbox top navigation even if allow-top-navigation is not set<span class="line"><!---->2. Bypassing sandbox top navigation even if allow-top-navigation is not set<!----></span><br>3. Bypassing CSP navigate-to (in Chrome beta) allowing navigation of other windows<span class="line"><!---->3. Bypassing CSP navigate-to (in Chrome beta) allowing navigation of other windows<!----></span><br><br>The first one is probably the one with the highest impact, as it allows for XSS. The same can be achieved by the other two as well but the blocks are not specifically targeted against javascript. The Navigation API seems to inherit CSP/sandbox restrictions from the target window not the initiating window<span class="line"><!---->The first one is probably the one with the highest impact, as it allows for XSS. The same can be achieved by the other two as well but the blocks are not specifically targeted against javascript. The Navigation API seems to inherit CSP/sandbox restrictions from the target window not the initiating window<!----></span><br><br># VERSION<span class="line"><!----># VERSION<!----></span><br>Chrome Version: <span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: <!----></span><br>Version 105.0.5195.127 (Official Build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Version 105.0.5195.127 (Official Build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Version 106.0.5249.30 (Official Build) beta (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Version 106.0.5249.30 (Official Build) beta (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Pro<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Pro<!----></span><br><br># REPRODUCTION CASE<span class="line"><!----># REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></span><br><br>## CSP script-src<span class="line"><!---->## CSP script-src<!----></span><br>A window with a strict CSP script-scr ('self' or script-src-attr) should not be able to trigger javascript execution by navigating any window to a javascript URL. Even if the window that is targeted does not by itself enforce a CSP. For example<span class="line"><!---->A window with a strict CSP script-scr ('self' or script-src-attr) should not be able to trigger javascript execution by navigating any window to a javascript URL. Even if the window that is targeted does not by itself enforce a CSP. For example<!----></span><br><br>window1 has CSP blocking unsafe inline scripts<span class="line"><!---->window1 has CSP blocking unsafe inline scripts<!----></span><br>window2 has no CSP<span class="line"><!---->window2 has no CSP<!----></span><br><br>window1 is blocked from running `window1.location = "javascript:alert()"` and also blocked from running `window2.location = "javascript:alert()"`. Window1's CSP should block all unsafe inline script execution originating from itself. But by running `window2.navigation.navigate("javascript:alert()")` window1 is able to run javascript in the context of window2. This requires two things<span class="line"><!---->window1 is blocked from running `window1.location = "javascript:alert()"` and also blocked from running `window2.location = "javascript:alert()"`. Window1's CSP should block all unsafe inline script execution originating from itself. But by running `window2.navigation.navigate("javascript:alert()")` window1 is able to run javascript in the context of window2. This requires two things<!----></span><br><br>1. Window2 allows unsafe inline scripts, or is lacking a CSP<span class="line"><!---->1. Window2 allows unsafe inline scripts, or is lacking a CSP<!----></span><br>2. Window1 have access to Window2's window object (they are same origin for example)<span class="line"><!---->2. Window1 have access to Window2's window object (they are same origin for example)<!----></span><br><br>This could be exploited in this scenario:<span class="line"><!---->This could be exploited in this scenario:<!----></span><br>A page without CSP contains an iframe of a page with a restrictive CSP (same origin). The framed page contains this button<span class="line"><!---->A page without CSP contains an iframe of a page with a restrictive CSP (same origin). The framed page contains this button<!----></span><br><br><button onclick='parent.navigation.navigate(URL)'>navigate</button><span class="line"><!---->&lt;button onclick='parent.navigation.navigate(URL)'&gt;navigate&lt;/button&gt;<!----></span><br><br>where URL is user controlled (say through a query parameter). A developer would think that this is safe from XSS as an URL with javascript scheme should be blocked by the CSP. This is not the case at the moment.<span class="line"><!---->where URL is user controlled (say through a query parameter). A developer would think that this is safe from XSS as an URL with javascript scheme should be blocked by the CSP. This is not the case at the moment.<!----></span><br><br># Top navigation<span class="line"><!----># Top navigation<!----></span><br><br>Framing a page with the iframe<span class="line"><!---->Framing a page with the iframe<!----></span><br><br><iframe sandbox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts" src="top_navigation.html"></iframe><span class="line"><!---->&lt;iframe sandbox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts" src="top_navigation.html"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;<!----></span><br><br>should block any attempts to navigate the top frame (the top window can apply a CSP for unsafe javascript to prevent the framed window adding script tags in the parent). But navigation.navigate bypasses this and the child frame can navigate the top window (to javascript urls as well if not restricted in the top window)<span class="line"><!---->should block any attempts to navigate the top frame (the top window can apply a CSP for unsafe javascript to prevent the framed window adding script tags in the parent). But navigation.navigate bypasses this and the child frame can navigate the top window (to javascript urls as well if not restricted in the top window)<!----></span><br><br># Navigate-to<span class="line"><!----># Navigate-to<!----></span><br><br>In chrome beta there is a CSP called navigate-to. This CSP restriction should block all navigation originating from the affected window. The document affected by this CSP rule can despite this still use navigation.navigate to navigate any window it have access to.<span class="line"><!---->In chrome beta there is a CSP called navigate-to. This CSP restriction should block all navigation originating from the affected window. The document affected by this CSP rule can despite this still use navigation.navigate to navigate any window it have access to.<!----></span><br><br>Reading in the specs for navigate-to <span class="line"><!---->Reading in the specs for navigate-to <!----></span>https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#directive-navigate-to<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#directive-navigate-to"><!---->https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#directive-navigate-to<!----></a> it is stated clearly that what navigate-to is supposed to block is ANY attempt to initialize a navigation from a document affected by it. Thus must include navigation.navigate. Trying the same trick with win.location = "<span class="line"><!----> it is stated clearly that what navigate-to is supposed to block is ANY attempt to initialize a navigation from a document affected by it. Thus must include navigation.navigate. Trying the same trick with win.location = "<!----></span>https://example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->https://example.com<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> will not work.<span class="line"><!----> will not work.<!----></span><br><br># What is happening<span class="line"><!----># What is happening<!----></span><br>I have not yet been able to track down the issue in the codebase. But I belive that using the Navigation API on another window inherits the CSP from the targeted window and not the initiating window. But I am not 100% sure of this. I strongly believe that you would want the new Navigation API to function as the old window.location action, inheriting and adhering to CSP and sandbox settings form the initiating window.<span class="line"><!---->I have not yet been able to track down the issue in the codebase. But I belive that using the Navigation API on another window inherits the CSP from the targeted window and not the initiating window. But I am not 100% sure of this. I strongly believe that you would want the new Navigation API to function as the old window.location action, inheriting and adhering to CSP and sandbox settings form the initiating window.<!----></span><br><br># POC<span class="line"><!----># POC<!----></span><br>I have created a page that contains the three described flaws. The navigate-to example will only work on Chrome BETA<span class="line"><!---->I have created a page that contains the three described flaws. The navigate-to example will only work on Chrome BETA<!----></span><br><br>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html<!----></a><br><br>Best regards<span class="line"><!---->Best regards<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Realized I forgot a description of the POC page.<span class="line"><!---->Realized I forgot a description of the POC page.<!----></span><br><br>Each iframe contains a button called "navigate" and one called "location". Open DevTools to monitor that clicking the "location" button (using window.location) will get blocked, while using the "navigation" button (using navigation.navigate) will not be blocked.<span class="line"><!---->Each iframe contains a button called "navigate" and one called "location". Open DevTools to monitor that clicking the "location" button (using window.location) will get blocked, while using the "navigation" button (using navigation.navigate) will not be blocked.<!----></span><br><br>Just to clarify, sorry about the lacking information!<span class="line"><!---->Just to clarify, sorry about the lacking information!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 8<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      domenic@chromium.org<a id="user-link" href="/u/1255490015" title="domenic@chromium.org"><!---->domenic@chromium.org<!----></a>
      domenic@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->domenic@chromium.org<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
      
        
          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          WontFix
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          WontFix
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I believe this is by design and none of these are security vulnerabilities. I believe they are based on a misunderstanding of what threat model each security feature is designed to protect.<span class="line"><!---->I believe this is by design and none of these are security vulnerabilities. I believe they are based on a misunderstanding of what threat model each security feature is designed to protect.<!----></span><br><br>For example, saying that script-src is meant to prevent window1 (which has CSP) from running script in window2 (with no CSP) is not correct. There are many existing ways window1 can run script in window2 given this setup. For example, eval. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing CSP spec.)<span class="line"><!---->For example, saying that script-src is meant to prevent window1 (which has CSP) from running script in window2 (with no CSP) is not correct. There are many existing ways window1 can run script in window2 given this setup. For example, eval. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing CSP spec.)<!----></span><br><br>Similarly, saying that top navigation is meant to be disallowed, in cases where allow-same-origin allow-scripts gives total script access to the top window, is not correct. There are many ways in which an allow-same-origin allow-scripts sandboxed iframe can navigate the top iframe already. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing HTML spec.)<span class="line"><!---->Similarly, saying that top navigation is meant to be disallowed, in cases where allow-same-origin allow-scripts gives total script access to the top window, is not correct. There are many ways in which an allow-same-origin allow-scripts sandboxed iframe can navigate the top iframe already. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing HTML spec.)<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the navigation API behaves differently from window.location was a conscious decision based on the fact that window.location actually sets the initiator to the incumbent window, whereas the navigation API always sets the initiator to the window whose navigate() method is being called. In other words, the security considerations that apply to window.location are not the same as those for window.navigation.navigate().<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the navigation API behaves differently from window.location was a conscious decision based on the fact that window.location actually sets the initiator to the incumbent window, whereas the navigation API always sets the initiator to the window whose navigate() method is being called. In other words, the security considerations that apply to window.location are not the same as those for window.navigation.navigate().<!----></span><br><br>As for navigate-to, my understanding is that feature (which is not enabled by default in Chrome beta, but instead a behind-a-flag feature in all Chrome versions) is not planned to be shipped.<span class="line"><!---->As for navigate-to, my understanding is that feature (which is not enabled by default in Chrome beta, but instead a behind-a-flag feature in all Chrome versions) is not planned to be shipped.<!----></span><br><br>I'll close this as WontFix, but if I've missed something that the OWP security folks are aware of, they can reopen.<span class="line"><!---->I'll close this as WontFix, but if I've missed something that the OWP security folks are aware of, they can reopen.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>

        by

        Just for the record here, I thought I would add what part of the functionality that caused my confusion. So even if it is intended behavior, the information is not super obvious to find.<span class="line"><!---->Just for the record here, I thought I would add what part of the functionality that caused my confusion. So even if it is intended behavior, the information is not super obvious to find.<!----></span><br><br>I have a page here: <span class="line"><!---->I have a page here: <!----></span>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation2.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation2.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation2.html<!----></a><br><br>The main page have a strict CSP only allowing nonce based scripts. The script on the page add event handlers on two buttons. The two buttons are used to "navigate" the framed window to a new page. Note that the framed page is from the same origin but lack a CSP. Using<span class="line"><!---->The main page have a strict CSP only allowing nonce based scripts. The script on the page add event handlers on two buttons. The two buttons are used to "navigate" the framed window to a new page. Note that the framed page is from the same origin but lack a CSP. Using<!----></span><br><br>frames[0].location.replace("javascript:alert(document.domain)");<span class="line"><!---->frames[0].location.replace("javascript:alert(document.domain)");<!----></span><br>frames[0].navigation.navigate("javascript:alert(document.domain)");<span class="line"><!---->frames[0].navigation.navigate("javascript:alert(document.domain)");<!----></span><br><br>will as you described behave different here as they have different "initiators". This is where I think a lot of developers might fall in to a trap when moving to the new API.<span class="line"><!---->will as you described behave different here as they have different "initiators". This is where I think a lot of developers might fall in to a trap when moving to the new API.<!----></span><br><br>This part here tries to describe differences between the two APIs: <span class="line"><!---->This part here tries to describe differences between the two APIs: <!----></span>https://github.com/WICG/navigation-api#the-navigate-and-reload-methods<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/WICG/navigation-api#the-navigate-and-reload-methods"><!---->https://github.com/WICG/navigation-api#the-navigate-and-reload-methods<!----></a><br><br>stating<span class="line"><!---->stating<!----></span><br>"""<span class="line"><!---->"""<!----></span><br>// Navigate to a new URL, resetting the state to undefined:<span class="line"><!---->// Navigate to a new URL, resetting the state to undefined:<!----></span><br>// (equivalent to `location.assign(url)`)<span class="line"><!---->// (equivalent to `location.assign(url)`)<!----></span><br>navigation.navigate(url);<span class="line"><!---->navigation.navigate(url);<!----></span><br><br>// Use a new URL and state.<span class="line"><!---->// Use a new URL and state.<!----></span><br>navigation.navigate(url, { state });<span class="line"><!---->navigation.navigate(url, { state });<!----></span><br><br>// You can also pass info for the navigate event handler to receive:<span class="line"><!---->// You can also pass info for the navigate event handler to receive:<!----></span><br>navigation.navigate(url, { state, info });<span class="line"><!---->navigation.navigate(url, { state, info });<!----></span><br>"""<span class="line"><!---->"""<!----></span><br><br>I did not find any discussion of CSP in the document.<span class="line"><!---->I did not find any discussion of CSP in the document.<!----></span><br><br>So a developer used to have the CSP from the calling window apply to the framed window on javascript navigation must replace their mental model now taking in consideration the framed windows CSP.<span class="line"><!---->So a developer used to have the CSP from the calling window apply to the framed window on javascript navigation must replace their mental model now taking in consideration the framed windows CSP.<!----></span><br><br>I also understand that there are multiple ways for an attacker that has full control of the JS on the framing page to achieve the same. What worries me is the javascript URL navigation as this is a source of many real word XSSes found on the internet. These vulnerabilities usually only allow an attacker to specify an URL (by query parameter or other means) that is subsequently used in the pages code. Developers who have relied on CSP to protect from these javascript urls being injected might expose themself to new attacks if they decide to move to the Navigation API without realizing the CSP scope difference between the APIs.<span class="line"><!---->I also understand that there are multiple ways for an attacker that has full control of the JS on the framing page to achieve the same. What worries me is the javascript URL navigation as this is a source of many real word XSSes found on the internet. These vulnerabilities usually only allow an attacker to specify an URL (by query parameter or other means) that is subsequently used in the pages code. Developers who have relied on CSP to protect from these javascript urls being injected might expose themself to new attacks if they decide to move to the Navigation API without realizing the CSP scope difference between the APIs.<!----></span><br><br>I hope this clarifies my concerns. I do still understand if you decide not to act on this, but I think the documentation should add this to the "security" part at least.<span class="line"><!---->I hope this clarifies my concerns. I do still understand if you decide not to act on this, but I think the documentation should add this to the "security" part at least.<!----></span><br><br>Best regards<span class="line"><!---->Best regards<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        After some testing I have to add a last bit of information. Using location.replace() on any window will actually take both the initiating and the target windows CSP into account. Giving the four cases <span class="line"><!---->After some testing I have to add a last bit of information. Using location.replace() on any window will actually take both the initiating and the target windows CSP into account. Giving the four cases <!----></span><br><br>1. A frame with no CSP can use location.replace() on another window which has no CSP block<span class="line"><!---->1. A frame with no CSP can use location.replace() on another window which has no CSP block<!----></span><br>2. A frame with no CSP can not use location.replace() on another window which has a CSP blocking scripts<span class="line"><!---->2. A frame with no CSP can not use location.replace() on another window which has a CSP blocking scripts<!----></span><br>3. A frame with script blocking CSP can not use location.replace() on another window with no CSP<span class="line"><!---->3. A frame with script blocking CSP can not use location.replace() on another window with no CSP<!----></span><br>4. A frame with script blocking CSP can not use location.replace() on another window which has a CSP blocking scripts<span class="line"><!---->4. A frame with script blocking CSP can not use location.replace() on another window which has a CSP blocking scripts<!----></span><br><br>As you can see only the first case can be used to navigate to a javascript URL. Trying to use the location API will use both windows CSP and use the hardest of them.<span class="line"><!---->As you can see only the first case can be used to navigate to a javascript URL. Trying to use the location API will use both windows CSP and use the hardest of them.<!----></span><br><br>With navigation API this is loosened to only use the CSP from the target window. The initiating windows CSP is ignored.<span class="line"><!---->With navigation API this is loosened to only use the CSP from the target window. The initiating windows CSP is ignored.<!----></span><br><br>You can try the location example here: <span class="line"><!---->You can try the location example here: <!----></span>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html<!----></a><br><br>And I forgot to upload my example files for the previous comment and will do it here (I used navigation2.html and no_csp.html for the previous comment. And nabigation3.html and csp.html and no_csp2.html for this one.)<span class="line"><!---->And I forgot to upload my example files for the previous comment and will do it here (I used navigation2.html and no_csp.html for the previous comment. And nabigation3.html and csp.html and no_csp2.html for this one.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 12<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by

        Yep, this is working as intended, as explained earlier! If you have complete JavaScript access to the other window (which is necessary to call that window's navigation.navigate() method), the navigation API gives no new powers.<span class="line"><!---->Yep, this is working as intended, as explained earlier! If you have complete JavaScript access to the other window (which is necessary to call that window's navigation.navigate() method), the navigation API gives no new powers.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Blocking:<strong><!---->Blocking:</strong>
          
            
      805886<a id="bugLink" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=805886"><!---->805886<!----></a><mr-issue-link projectname="chromium" text="805886"></mr-issue-link>
          
          
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Blocking:</strong>
          <!---->
            <mr-issue-link projectname="chromium" text="805886"></mr-issue-link>
          <!---->
          
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Thanks for this report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for this report!<!----></span><br><br>TLDR: The navigation API is interesting, because it sets the initiator of the navigation differently. It uses the callee of the navigation API instead of the caller. This is something new that I wasn't aware of. This is something to explore, it might have interesting security implications. However, in the case of the bug report, I don't see anything worrying, Firefox and recent versions of Chrome display "An iframe which has both allow-scripts and allow-same-origin for its sandbox attribute can remove its sandboxing". There are many ways to escape the sandbox as Domenick said.<span class="line"><!---->TLDR: The navigation API is interesting, because it sets the initiator of the navigation differently. It uses the callee of the navigation API instead of the caller. This is something new that I wasn't aware of. This is something to explore, it might have interesting security implications. However, in the case of the bug report, I don't see anything worrying, Firefox and recent versions of Chrome display "An iframe which has both allow-scripts and allow-same-origin for its sandbox attribute can remove its sandboxing". There are many ways to escape the sandbox as Domenick said.<!----></span><br><br>However, it means the navigation API is going to block shipping CSP:navigate-to, because it provides a way to trivially bypass it. I am adding it as a blocker.<span class="line"><!---->However, it means the navigation API is going to block shipping CSP:navigate-to, because it provides a way to trivially bypass it. I am adding it as a blocker.<!----></span><br><br><br>The long version of what I tried:<span class="line"><!---->The long version of what I tried:<!----></span><br><br># <span class="line"><!----># <!----></span>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html<!----></a><br><br>## Running script despite CSP script block<span class="line"><!---->## Running script despite CSP script block<!----></span><br><br>Evaluating JS in the parent was blocked by the parent CSP in both case. It seems to be WAI to me.<span class="line"><!---->Evaluating JS in the parent was blocked by the parent CSP in both case. It seems to be WAI to me.<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>javascript.html:2 Refused to run the JavaScript URL because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'none'". Either the 'unsafe-inline' keyword, a hash ('sha256-...'), or a nonce ('nonce-...') is required to enable inline execution. Note that hashes do not apply to event handlers, style attributes and javascript: navigations unless the 'unsafe-hashes' keyword is present.<span class="line"><!---->javascript.html:2 Refused to run the JavaScript URL because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'none'". Either the 'unsafe-inline' keyword, a hash ('sha256-...'), or a nonce ('nonce-...') is required to enable inline execution. Note that hashes do not apply to event handlers, style attributes and javascript: navigations unless the 'unsafe-hashes' keyword is present.<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br><br>## Navigating top window despite sandbox<span class="line"><!---->## Navigating top window despite sandbox<!----></span><br><br>In Firefox, and in recent version of Chrome, we display:<span class="line"><!---->In Firefox, and in recent version of Chrome, we display:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>An iframe which has both allow-scripts and allow-same-origin for its sandbox attribute can remove its sandboxing.<span class="line"><!---->An iframe which has both allow-scripts and allow-same-origin for its sandbox attribute can remove its sandboxing.<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>"navigate js", "location js" "location site" are blocked.<span class="line"><!---->"navigate js", "location js" "location site" are blocked.<!----></span><br>"navigate site" is not blocked. It corresponds to "parent.navigation.navigate("<span class="line"><!---->"navigate site" is not blocked. It corresponds to "parent.navigation.navigate("<!----></span>https://example.com")"<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com&quot;)&quot;"><!---->https://example.com")"<!----></a><br><br>## Navigating any window despite navigate-to<span class="line"><!---->## Navigating any window despite navigate-to<!----></span><br><br>I haven't tried, but I guess the new "navigation" API allows you to initiate navigation, despite CSP. This would indeed be a blocker for shipping CSP:navigate-to.<span class="line"><!---->I haven't tried, but I guess the new "navigation" API allows you to initiate navigation, despite CSP. This would indeed be a blocker for shipping CSP:navigate-to.<!----></span><br><br><br># <span class="line"><!----># <!----></span>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html<!----></a><br><br>## This page has a CSP: script-src 'none'<span class="line"><!---->## This page has a CSP: script-src 'none'<!----></span><br><br>Execution of JS is blocked by CSP, this is WAI<span class="line"><!---->Execution of JS is blocked by CSP, this is WAI<!----></span><br><br>## This page has no CSP<span class="line"><!---->## This page has no CSP<!----></span><br><br>Execution of JS is blocked when targeting the CSP:script-src 'none' document, and isn't blocked when targeting the main document where there are no CSP.<span class="line"><!---->Execution of JS is blocked when targeting the CSP:script-src 'none' document, and isn't blocked when targeting the main document where there are no CSP.<!----></span><br>This is working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->This is working as intended.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for answering here!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for answering here!<!----></span><br><br>arthursonzogni@google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/arthursonzogni@google.com"><!---->arthursonzogni@google.com<!----></a> : I now updated the <span class="line"><!----> : I now updated the <!----></span>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation3.html<!----></a> example to more clearly prove my point. As you can see there are two buttons that work in the right iframe but only one that work in the left one. I understand that this might just be a sideefect of the way it is implemented (caller vs callee). But it shows that the two ways treat CSP differently. The old history API seems to merge the two CSPs where Navigation API only check the CSP on the window object used to call it.<span class="line"><!----> example to more clearly prove my point. As you can see there are two buttons that work in the right iframe but only one that work in the left one. I understand that this might just be a sideefect of the way it is implemented (caller vs callee). But it shows that the two ways treat CSP differently. The old history API seems to merge the two CSPs where Navigation API only check the CSP on the window object used to call it.<!----></span><br><br>Where I see an issue with this is the documentation describing Navigation API as a replacement for history. As their API does not line up. Taking user input as the URL in this described scenario would change the behaviour if a developer blindly switches out the API's used.<span class="line"><!---->Where I see an issue with this is the documentation describing Navigation API as a replacement for history. As their API does not line up. Taking user input as the URL in this described scenario would change the behaviour if a developer blindly switches out the API's used.<!----></span><br><br>To my last question, can I mention this discrepancy in a blog post or do you want me to wait for anything here?<span class="line"><!---->To my last question, can I mention this discrepancy in a blog post or do you want me to wait for anything here?<!----></span><br><br>Thanks again for getting back!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks again for getting back!<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          flex-flow: column;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          align-items: stretch;
        }
        mr-launch-overview[hidden] {
          display: none;
        }
        mr-phase {
          margin-bottom: 0.75em;
        }
      </style>
      
      
    <!----></mr-launch-overview>
            </div>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        for LitElement.

          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;

        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;

          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }

          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);

        }

          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);

      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;

          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

            Got it
          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>

          </chops-button>

      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

            Issue 1363311: Security: Navigation API can be used to bypass multiple CSP and sandbox restrictions
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1363311: Security: Navigation API can be used to bypass multiple CSP and sandbox restrictions
          </h1>
          
            Reported by
            
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      johan...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/3529797889" title="johan...@gmail.com"><!---->johan...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      johan...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->johan...@gmail.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on

        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1363311: Security: Navigation API can be used to bypass multiple CSP and sandbox restrictions
          </h1>
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Sep 13, 2022, 4:28 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
            
          </small>
        </div>
      <div class="main-text-outer">
        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1363311: Security: Navigation API can be used to bypass multiple CSP and sandbox restrictions
          </h1>
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>

      I reported a first finding of this (before I understood the deeper impact here) but it got closed as wont-fix. I tried to contact you in the original report but have gotten no answer, so I will try opening the new report. The other report is <span class="line"><!---->I reported a first finding of this (before I understood the deeper impact here) but it got closed as wont-fix. I tried to contact you in the original report but have gotten no answer, so I will try opening the new report. The other report is <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1354624<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1354624"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1354624<!----></a> . I am sorry if this is the wrong way to go about this. Please reply to me with instructions if you want me to take this some other way.<span class="line"><!----> . I am sorry if this is the wrong way to go about this. Please reply to me with instructions if you want me to take this some other way.<!----></span><br><br># VULNERABILITY DETAILS<span class="line"><!----># VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></span><br>The navigation API allows a CSP/sandboxed document to perform multiple actions that violate these restrictions. I have so far identified three actions that have a security impact. The API allows<span class="line"><!---->The navigation API allows a CSP/sandboxed document to perform multiple actions that violate these restrictions. I have so far identified three actions that have a security impact. The API allows<!----></span><br><br>1. Bypassing CSP script-src by navigating another window to a javascript URL<span class="line"><!---->1. Bypassing CSP script-src by navigating another window to a javascript URL<!----></span><br>2. Bypassing sandbox top navigation even if allow-top-navigation is not set<span class="line"><!---->2. Bypassing sandbox top navigation even if allow-top-navigation is not set<!----></span><br>3. Bypassing CSP navigate-to (in Chrome beta) allowing navigation of other windows<span class="line"><!---->3. Bypassing CSP navigate-to (in Chrome beta) allowing navigation of other windows<!----></span><br><br>The first one is probably the one with the highest impact, as it allows for XSS. The same can be achieved by the other two as well but the blocks are not specifically targeted against javascript. The Navigation API seems to inherit CSP/sandbox restrictions from the target window not the initiating window<span class="line"><!---->The first one is probably the one with the highest impact, as it allows for XSS. The same can be achieved by the other two as well but the blocks are not specifically targeted against javascript. The Navigation API seems to inherit CSP/sandbox restrictions from the target window not the initiating window<!----></span><br><br># VERSION<span class="line"><!----># VERSION<!----></span><br>Chrome Version: <span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: <!----></span><br>Version 105.0.5195.127 (Official Build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Version 105.0.5195.127 (Official Build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Version 106.0.5249.30 (Official Build) beta (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Version 106.0.5249.30 (Official Build) beta (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Pro<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Pro<!----></span><br><br># REPRODUCTION CASE<span class="line"><!----># REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></span><br><br>## CSP script-src<span class="line"><!---->## CSP script-src<!----></span><br>A window with a strict CSP script-scr ('self' or script-src-attr) should not be able to trigger javascript execution by navigating any window to a javascript URL. Even if the window that is targeted does not by itself enforce a CSP. For example<span class="line"><!---->A window with a strict CSP script-scr ('self' or script-src-attr) should not be able to trigger javascript execution by navigating any window to a javascript URL. Even if the window that is targeted does not by itself enforce a CSP. For example<!----></span><br><br>window1 has CSP blocking unsafe inline scripts<span class="line"><!---->window1 has CSP blocking unsafe inline scripts<!----></span><br>window2 has no CSP<span class="line"><!---->window2 has no CSP<!----></span><br><br>window1 is blocked from running `window1.location = "javascript:alert()"` and also blocked from running `window2.location = "javascript:alert()"`. Window1's CSP should block all unsafe inline script execution originating from itself. But by running `window2.navigation.navigate("javascript:alert()")` window1 is able to run javascript in the context of window2. This requires two things<span class="line"><!---->window1 is blocked from running `window1.location = "javascript:alert()"` and also blocked from running `window2.location = "javascript:alert()"`. Window1's CSP should block all unsafe inline script execution originating from itself. But by running `window2.navigation.navigate("javascript:alert()")` window1 is able to run javascript in the context of window2. This requires two things<!----></span><br><br>1. Window2 allows unsafe inline scripts, or is lacking a CSP<span class="line"><!---->1. Window2 allows unsafe inline scripts, or is lacking a CSP<!----></span><br>2. Window1 have access to Window2's window object (they are same origin for example)<span class="line"><!---->2. Window1 have access to Window2's window object (they are same origin for example)<!----></span><br><br>This could be exploited in this scenario:<span class="line"><!---->This could be exploited in this scenario:<!----></span><br>A page without CSP contains an iframe of a page with a restrictive CSP (same origin). The framed page contains this button<span class="line"><!---->A page without CSP contains an iframe of a page with a restrictive CSP (same origin). The framed page contains this button<!----></span><br><br><button onclick='parent.navigation.navigate(URL)'>navigate</button><span class="line"><!---->&lt;button onclick='parent.navigation.navigate(URL)'&gt;navigate&lt;/button&gt;<!----></span><br><br>where URL is user controlled (say through a query parameter). A developer would think that this is safe from XSS as an URL with javascript scheme should be blocked by the CSP. This is not the case at the moment.<span class="line"><!---->where URL is user controlled (say through a query parameter). A developer would think that this is safe from XSS as an URL with javascript scheme should be blocked by the CSP. This is not the case at the moment.<!----></span><br><br># Top navigation<span class="line"><!----># Top navigation<!----></span><br><br>Framing a page with the iframe<span class="line"><!---->Framing a page with the iframe<!----></span><br><br><iframe sandbox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts" src="top_navigation.html"></iframe><span class="line"><!---->&lt;iframe sandbox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts" src="top_navigation.html"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;<!----></span><br><br>should block any attempts to navigate the top frame (the top window can apply a CSP for unsafe javascript to prevent the framed window adding script tags in the parent). But navigation.navigate bypasses this and the child frame can navigate the top window (to javascript urls as well if not restricted in the top window)<span class="line"><!---->should block any attempts to navigate the top frame (the top window can apply a CSP for unsafe javascript to prevent the framed window adding script tags in the parent). But navigation.navigate bypasses this and the child frame can navigate the top window (to javascript urls as well if not restricted in the top window)<!----></span><br><br># Navigate-to<span class="line"><!----># Navigate-to<!----></span><br><br>In chrome beta there is a CSP called navigate-to. This CSP restriction should block all navigation originating from the affected window. The document affected by this CSP rule can despite this still use navigation.navigate to navigate any window it have access to.<span class="line"><!---->In chrome beta there is a CSP called navigate-to. This CSP restriction should block all navigation originating from the affected window. The document affected by this CSP rule can despite this still use navigation.navigate to navigate any window it have access to.<!----></span><br><br>Reading in the specs for navigate-to <span class="line"><!---->Reading in the specs for navigate-to <!----></span>https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#directive-navigate-to<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#directive-navigate-to"><!---->https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#directive-navigate-to<!----></a> it is stated clearly that what navigate-to is supposed to block is ANY attempt to initialize a navigation from a document affected by it. Thus must include navigation.navigate. Trying the same trick with win.location = "<span class="line"><!----> it is stated clearly that what navigate-to is supposed to block is ANY attempt to initialize a navigation from a document affected by it. Thus must include navigation.navigate. Trying the same trick with win.location = "<!----></span>https://example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->https://example.com<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> will not work.<span class="line"><!----> will not work.<!----></span><br><br># What is happening<span class="line"><!----># What is happening<!----></span><br>I have not yet been able to track down the issue in the codebase. But I belive that using the Navigation API on another window inherits the CSP from the targeted window and not the initiating window. But I am not 100% sure of this. I strongly believe that you would want the new Navigation API to function as the old window.location action, inheriting and adhering to CSP and sandbox settings form the initiating window.<span class="line"><!---->I have not yet been able to track down the issue in the codebase. But I belive that using the Navigation API on another window inherits the CSP from the targeted window and not the initiating window. But I am not 100% sure of this. I strongly believe that you would want the new Navigation API to function as the old window.location action, inheriting and adhering to CSP and sandbox settings form the initiating window.<!----></span><br><br># POC<span class="line"><!----># POC<!----></span><br>I have created a page that contains the three described flaws. The navigate-to example will only work on Chrome BETA<span class="line"><!---->I have created a page that contains the three described flaws. The navigate-to example will only work on Chrome BETA<!----></span><br><br>https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html"><!---->https://joaxcar.com/chrome/navigation.html<!----></a><br><br>Best regards<span class="line"><!---->Best regards<!----></span><br>Johan<span class="line"><!---->Johan<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Realized I forgot a description of the POC page.<span class="line"><!---->Realized I forgot a description of the POC page.<!----></span><br><br>Each iframe contains a button called "navigate" and one called "location".           Comment 8<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      domenic@chromium.org<a id="user-link" href="/u/1255490015" title="domenic@chromium.org"><!---->domenic@chromium.org<!----></a>
      domenic@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->domenic@chromium.org<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1363311#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Sep 15, 2022, 5:55 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
      
        
          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          WontFix
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          WontFix
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I believe this is by design and none of these are security vulnerabilities. I believe they are based on a misunderstanding of what threat model each security feature is designed to protect.<span class="line"><!---->I believe this is by design and none of these are security vulnerabilities. I believe they are based on a misunderstanding of what threat model each security feature is designed to protect.<!----></span><br><br>For example, saying that script-src is meant to prevent window1 (which has CSP) from running script in window2 (with no CSP) is not correct. There are many existing ways window1 can run script in window2 given this setup. For example, eval. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing CSP spec.)<span class="line"><!---->For example, saying that script-src is meant to prevent window1 (which has CSP) from running script in window2 (with no CSP) is not correct. There are many existing ways window1 can run script in window2 given this setup. For example, eval. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing CSP spec.)<!----></span><br><br>Similarly, saying that top navigation is meant to be disallowed, in cases where allow-same-origin allow-scripts gives total script access to the top window, is not correct. There are many ways in which an allow-same-origin allow-scripts sandboxed iframe can navigate the top iframe already. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing HTML spec.)<span class="line"><!---->Similarly, saying that top navigation is meant to be disallowed, in cases where allow-same-origin allow-scripts gives total script access to the top window, is not correct. There are many ways in which an allow-same-origin allow-scripts sandboxed iframe can navigate the top iframe already. (This is explicitly allowed by the existing HTML spec.)<!----></span><br><br>The fact that the navigation API behaves differently from window.location was a conscious decision based on the fact that window.location actually sets the initiator to the incumbent window, whereas the navigation API always sets the initiator to the window whose navigate() method is being called. In other words, the security considerations that apply to window.location are not the same as those for window.navigation.navigate().<span class="line"><!---->The fact that the navigation API behaves differently from window.location was a conscious decision based on the fact that window.location actually sets the initiator to the incumbent window, whereas the navigation API always sets the initiator to the window whose navigate() method is being called. In other words, the security considerations that apply to window.location are not the same as those for window.navigation.navigate().<!----></span><br><br>As for navigate-to, my understanding is that feature (which is not enabled by default in Chrome beta, but instead a behind-a-flag feature in all Chrome versions) is not planned to be shipped.<span class="line"><!---->As for navigate-to, my understanding is that feature (which is not enabled by default in Chrome beta, but instead a behind-a-flag feature in all Chrome versions) is not planned to be shipped.<!----></span><br><br>I'll close this as WontFix, but if I've missed something that the OWP security folks are aware of, they can reopen.<span class="line"><!---->I'll close this as WontFix, but if I've missed something that the OWP security folks are aware of, they can reopen.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>
